articles.headline: Amex, Challenged by Chase, Is Losing the Snob War
articles.snippet: Amex’s hold on the affluent fantasies of up-and-coming elites is starting to wobble as other credit card companies are beating it at its own game.
articles.abstract: Amex’s hold on the affluent fantasies of up-and-coming elites is starting to wobble as other credit card companies are beating it at its own game.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand the anxiety inside American Express — which has announced its second consecutive year of declining revenue — you need to know about a story that made its way through the company’s headquarters last fall.

articles.headline: Does a Uniform Keep Officers in Line? The Baltimore Chief Thinks So
articles.snippet: The plainclothes ‘jump-out boys,’ long the subject of complaints, were disbanded after seven members were charged with stealing drugs, firearms and money.
articles.abstract: The plainclothes ‘jump-out boys,’ long the subject of complaints, were disbanded after seven members were charged with stealing drugs, firearms and money.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Abdul-Jaami Salaam felt his heartbeat quicken the minute he saw what the police officers were wearing: jeans, T-shirts and bulletproof vests. “Here come the cowboys,” he thought.

articles.headline: White House to Keep Its Visitor Logs Secret
articles.snippet: The White House also said it was ending the contract for the website that contains the visitor log data as well as financial disclosure and salary information for employees.
articles.abstract: The White House also said it was ending the contract for the website that contains the visitor log data as well as financial disclosure and salary information for employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The White House announced Friday that it would cut off public access to visitor logs revealing who is entering the White House complex and which officials they are meeting, breaking with the Obama administration’s practice and returning a cloak of secrecy over the basic day-to-day workings of the government.

articles.headline: Robert Taylor, Innovator Who Shaped Modern Computing, Dies at 85
articles.snippet: Mr. Taylor’s work was instrumental in the creation of the internet, the modern personal computer and the mouse.
articles.abstract: Mr. Taylor’s work was instrumental in the creation of the internet, the modern personal computer and the mouse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many inventions, the internet was the work of countless hands. But perhaps no one deserves more credit for that world-changing technological leap than Robert W. Taylor, who died on Thursday at 85 at his home in Woodside, Calif.

articles.headline: Defiant, Generic Drug Maker Continues to Raise Prices
articles.snippet: Despite scrutiny from federal and state investigators, shares of Lannett Company are up 15 percent this year to date.
articles.abstract: Despite scrutiny from federal and state investigators, shares of Lannett Company are up 15 percent this year to date.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional hearings. Federal investigations. Consumer outrage.

articles.headline: DeVos Halts Obama-Era Plan to Revamp Student Loan Management
articles.snippet: In another reversal of previous policies, President Trump’s education secretary hit the reset button on a plan to streamline a much-maligned patchwork of loan servicers.
articles.abstract: In another reversal of previous policies, President Trump’s education secretary hit the reset button on a plan to streamline a much-maligned patchwork of loan servicers.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the stroke of a pen this week, Betsy DeVos, President Trump’s new education secretary, thrust the future of the government’s system for managing federal student loans into confusion.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: O’Reilly’s Behavior Said to Have Helped Drive Megyn Kelly Out at Fox
articles.snippet: Bill O’Reilly’s response to complaints about sexual harassment at Fox News prompted Ms. Kelly, a rising star at the network, to send an angry email to top executives. She later jumped to NBC.
articles.abstract: Bill O’Reilly’s response to complaints about sexual harassment at Fox News prompted Ms. Kelly, a rising star at the network, to send an angry email to top executives. She later jumped to NBC.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, in the weeks after 21st Century Fox struck settlements with two women who said that Bill O’Reilly had sexually harassed them, the Fox News host went on morning television and offered a harsh assessment of women who had come forward with complaints about the network.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Is American Retail at a Historic Tipping Point?
articles.snippet: The profound reordering of New York’s shopping scene reflects a broad restructuring in the American retail industry.
articles.abstract: The profound reordering of New York’s shopping scene reflects a broad restructuring in the American retail industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Along the cobblestone streets of SoHo, Chanel handbags and Arc’teryx jackets are displayed in shops like museum pieces, harking back to the height of the neighborhood’s trendiness. But rents there are softening, and the number of vacant storefronts is rising.

articles.headline: As Atrocities Mount in Syria, Justice Seems Out of Reach
articles.snippet: A mountain of evidence has been compiled against Syrian officials for war crimes from torture to summary killings. But there is no clear path to justice.
articles.abstract: A mountain of evidence has been compiled against Syrian officials for war crimes from torture to summary killings. But there is no clear path to justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The evidence is staggering.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard, Ben Hubbard and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: Federal Judge Blocks Arkansas Executions
articles.snippet: A federal judge halted Arkansas’ plans for an extraordinary series of executions set to begin on Monday. A state judge’s ruling had already put the schedule in doubt.
articles.abstract: A federal judge halted Arkansas’ plans for an extraordinary series of executions set to begin on Monday. A state judge’s ruling had already put the schedule in doubt.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Saturday halted Arkansas’ plans for an extraordinary series of executions set to begin on Monday, adding to the legal chaos surrounding what began as one state’s effort to put eight convicted murderers to death over less than two weeks.

articles.headline: Marijuana Goes Industrial in California
articles.snippet: Growers are moving to large farms in the Salinas Valley, threatening the state’s smaller cannabis farmers and inspiring fears of a glut.
articles.abstract: Growers are moving to large farms in the Salinas Valley, threatening the state’s smaller cannabis farmers and inspiring fears of a glut.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALINAS, Calif. — This vast and fertile valley is often called the salad bowl of the nation for the countless heads of lettuce growing across its floor. Now California’s marijuana industry is laying claim to a new slogan for the valley: America’s cannabis bucket.

articles.headline: Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump: Pillars of Family-Driven West Wing
articles.snippet: As the president has soured on Stephen K. Bannon, Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump have emerged as President Trump’s most important advisers, at least for now.
articles.abstract: As the president has soured on Stephen K. Bannon, Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump have emerged as President Trump’s most important advisers, at least for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One has an office down the hall from the president in the White House; the other just moved into an office a floor up. One recently visited war-torn Iraq as the president’s emissary; the other will soon head to Berlin at the invitation of Germany’s chancellor.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: With Trump Appointees, a Raft of Potential Conflicts and ‘No Transparency’
articles.snippet: President Trump is populating the federal government with former lobbyists who in many cases are influencing policy in industries where they were recently paid.
articles.abstract: President Trump is populating the federal government with former lobbyists who in many cases are influencing policy in industries where they were recently paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is populating the White House and federal agencies with former lobbyists, lawyers and consultants who in many cases are helping to craft new policies for the same industries in which they recently earned a paycheck.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Ben Protess and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Mexican Deportees, Once Ignored Back Home, Now Find ‘Open Arms’
articles.snippet: The number of Mexicans kicked out of the United States actually fell at the start of President Trump’s term, but politicians and others in Mexico have seized on the issue.
articles.abstract: The number of Mexicans kicked out of the United States actually fell at the start of President Trump’s term, but politicians and others in Mexico have seized on the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s president dashed to the airport to greet a planeload of deportees. The education minister rushed to the Texas border to meet Mexicans being kicked out of the United States. Mexico City’s labor secretary is urging companies to hire migrants who abruptly find themselves sent back home.

articles.headline: Erdogan Claims Vast Powers in Turkey After Narrow Victory in Referendum
articles.snippet: The main opposition demanded a recount and warned that the vote might cement authoritarian rule within one of the critical power brokers of the Middle East.
articles.abstract: The main opposition demanded a recount and warned that the vote might cement authoritarian rule within one of the critical power brokers of the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A slim majority of Turkish voters agreed on Sunday to grant sweeping powers to their president, in a watershed moment that the country’s opposition fears may cement a system of authoritarian rule within one of the critical power brokers of the Middle East.

articles.headline: Slack, an Upstart in Messaging, Now Faces Giant Tech Rivals
articles.snippet: Microsoft and Facebook have rolled out competing tools. But Slack’s chief executive says small tech companies with new ideas have a history of defeating the big guys.
articles.abstract: Microsoft and Facebook have rolled out competing tools. But Slack’s chief executive says small tech companies with new ideas have a history of defeating the big guys.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Slack is the classic Silicon Valley accidental success. Born three years ago, with roots in a failed video game, the messaging software is now used by five million people.

articles.headline: Mike Conaway Emerges From Relative Obscurity to Lead House Russia Inquiry
articles.snippet: Mr. Conaway, a Texas Republican who is the chairman of the Agriculture Committee, is the accidental heir to a potentially explosive investigation.
articles.abstract: Mr. Conaway, a Texas Republican who is the chairman of the Agriculture Committee, is the accidental heir to a potentially explosive investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex. — President Trump does not know Mike Conaway.

articles.headline: After Economic Crisis, Low Birthrates Challenge Southern Europe
articles.snippet: A hot spot for childlessness is rising in Greece and neighboring countries, heralding weaker growth and productivity, and creating fiscal problems.
articles.abstract: A hot spot for childlessness is rising in Greece and neighboring countries, heralding weaker growth and productivity, and creating fiscal problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As a longtime fertility doctor, Minas Mastrominas has helped couples in Greece give birth to thousands of bouncing babies. But recently, disturbing trends have escalated at his clinic.

articles.headline: Car Chases, Cute Newcomers and Familiar Faces: Plotting a Turnaround at Sony Pictures
articles.snippet: The studio’s movie chairman, Thomas Rothman, has several promising films scheduled for release, but whether one will be the megahit he needs is uncertain.
articles.abstract: The studio’s movie chairman, Thomas Rothman, has several promising films scheduled for release, but whether one will be the megahit he needs is uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — A gladiator, indeed.

articles.headline: Inside the Hotel Industry’s Plan to Combat Airbnb
articles.snippet: Newly obtained documents show how the American Hotel and Lodging Association is taking steps to curb the online short-term rental company.
articles.abstract: Newly obtained documents show how the American Hotel and Lodging Association is taking steps to curb the online short-term rental company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last year, Airbnb underwent a rough regulatory patch.

articles.headline: A Lesson in Moscow About Trump-Style ‘Alternative Truth’
articles.snippet: Watching Russian television and hearing journalists’ war stories, I wondered if I had arrived through an alt-right wormhole.
articles.abstract: Watching Russian television and hearing journalists’ war stories, I wondered if I had arrived through an alt-right wormhole.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — I wanted to better understand President Trump’s America, a place where truth is being ripped from its moorings as he brands those tasked with lashing it back into place — journalists — as dishonest enemies of the people.

articles.headline: A ‘Cuban Missile Crisis in Slow Motion’ in North Korea
articles.snippet: As the standoff grows under a new American president, a mix of national ambitions, personal ego and deadly weapons is creating opportunities for miscalculation.
articles.abstract: As the standoff grows under a new American president, a mix of national ambitions, personal ego and deadly weapons is creating opportunities for miscalculation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — All the elements of the North Korean nuclear crisis — the relentless drive by Kim Jong-un to assemble an arsenal, the propaganda and deception swirling around his progress, the hints of a covert war by the United States to undermine the effort, rather than be forced into open confrontation — were on vivid display this weekend.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Trump Voters in a Swing District Wonder When the ‘Winning’ Will Start
articles.snippet: In a swing county of a swing region of a swing state that powered Donald J. Trump’s victory, some residents are starting to regret having supported him.
articles.abstract: In a swing county of a swing region of a swing state that powered Donald J. Trump’s victory, some residents are starting to regret having supported him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENSALEM, Pa. — One after another, the gamblers totter along the twisting walkway, bathed in artificial purple light — burdened, at least occasionally, by the instinct that they should have known better.

articles.headline: In Supporting Erdogan, Turks Cite Economic and Religious Gains
articles.snippet: Voters in major cities tended to oppose the changes expanding presidential power, but those in rural areas, who are often more religious, voted for them.
articles.abstract: Voters in major cities tended to oppose the changes expanding presidential power, but those in rural areas, who are often more religious, voted for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Merve Arslan, a teacher, struggles to reconcile her own perception of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey with that of his critics. “He’s not a dictator,” Ms. Arslan, 28, said. “He’s a democrat.”
